body:
This adds a configuration for the official language server for the Nextflow scientific pipeline language.

This language server is relatively new, but is part of an initiative to modernize their editor language support. It is an industry standard tool for developing scientific pipelines especially in the epidemiology/genomics community both academic and industry. It is an officially supported project by the language's organization so I'm hoping that is enough to vet it for getting added.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
https://github.com/nextflow-io/language-server
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,37 @@
+local util = require 'lspconfig.util'
+
+return {
+  default_config = {
+    cmd = { 'java', '-jar', 'nextflow-language-server-all.jar' },
+    filetypes = { 'nextflow' },
+    root_dir = function(fname)
+      return util.root_pattern('nextflow.config')(fname) or util.find_git_ancestor(fname)
+    end,
+    settings = {
+      nextflow = {
+        files = {
+          exclude = { '.git', '.nf-test', 'work' },
+        },
+      },
+    },
+  },
+  docs = {
+    description = [[
+https://github.com/nextflow-io/language-server.git

comment_data.body:
Yeah totally understand, the main reason for mentioning it's official from the programming language was to hope that could vet the validity of the language server early, especially since having it easily integrated into editors and adding that into the documentation on the editor modernization can help drive users rather than vice versa. I can close this and wait until it reaches the star count.

One question I do have is the VS code plugin for the language server will definitely get a lot more attention in the community early on and will get most of the stars just because that's what users who use this project will mainly be referencing. Would those stars help count towards this vetting process?

comment_data.body:
Ah, okay that's great. So just to make sure I follow, if I have this directory structure:

```
project1/
- nextflow.config
- some_folder/
  - .git/
  - test_file
```

And use the revised block while editing `test_file`, I'll get a root at `project1` and _not_ `some_folder`?

Okay I pushed an update with this. I'm still not at a computer but I see now why the GitHub UI got the wrong commit message. It looks like you committed the suggestion I made before I was able to type out the commit message  I think this PR is ready to go if you could revise your commit message for the tests can pass.


Thanks again!

+local util = require 'lspconfig.util'
+
+return {
+  default_config = {
+    cmd = { 'java', '-jar', 'nextflow-language-server-all.jar' },
+    filetypes = { 'nextflow' },
+    root_dir = util.root_pattern('nextflow.config', '.git'),
+    settings = {
+      nextflow = {
+        files = {
+          exclude = { '.git', '.nf-test', 'work' },
+        },
+      },
+    },
+  },
+  docs = {
+    description = [[
+https://github.com/nextflow-io/language-server
+
+Requirements:
+ - Java 17+
+
+`nextflow_ls` can be installed by following the instructions [here](https://github.com/nextflow-io/language-server#development).
+
+If you have installed nextflow language server, you can set the `cmd` custom path as follow:
+
+```lua
+require'lspconfig'.nextflow_ls.setup{
+    cmd = { "java", "-jar", "path/to/nextflow_ls/language-server-all.jar" },
+    ...

comment_data.body: Is this correct? The user doesn't need to fully specify the file types and things when they are simply setting up the language server. They just need to make sure to potentially update the command with the path to the jar. This doc string was also basically a direct copy of the groovy_ls doc string in this repository.

title: feat: add the official Nextflow Language Server (`nextflow_ls`)
